titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Remsen and Schenk family papers 1985.017
titlestmt.author: Originally processed and described by D.S. Moore with research by Ariadne Valsamis. Matthew Gorham later created a collection-level digital record.
titlestmt.sponsor: In 2011, this collection was described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-07-30 14:52:48 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The Remsen and Schenk family papers are comprised of various land and legal documents, including deeds, mortgages, wills, and conveyances to land primarily in Brooklyn. Most documents concern property owned by the Remsen and Schenk families.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Upon reporocessing in 2024, the original 1985 arrangement was retained. The collection is arranged into four series. Series 1 consists of documents relating to the Remsen family. Series 2 consists of documents relating to the Schenk family. Series 3 consists of other Brooklyn land documents. The items are housed together by series except for oversize items, which are together in their own folder.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Remsen and Schenk family papers, 1985.017, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2024.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Brooklyn Historical Society Genealogical vertical files (ARC.313), Folder: Remsen
Garrit S.K. Remsen accounts and collection records for Flatlands School District No.2 (1977.493)
Teunis G. Bergen and Bergen family collection (ARC.006)
March, Middagh, and Sands families property records (1974.038)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Remsen and Schenk family papers are comprised of various land and legal documents, including deeds, mortgages, wills, and conveyances to land primarily in Brooklyn. Most documents concern property owned by the Remsen and Schenk families. The collection relates to the following farmers: Jacob Remsen (1719-1794), Joris Remsen (1721-1794) Martin Schenk (1796-1823) and Lambert Schenk (1796-1815).

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Announcement of Jacob and Joris Remsen that they are claiming the land left to them by their father upon his death. The land is three small parcels on the south side of the road to the ferry, adjoining the property of John Nostrand and Cornelius Duryea in the Town of "Bruckland" near "Flatbush Meadows." The family homestead was apparently named "Crupelbush." This copy was signed by Jacob.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Same as above, except signed by Joris Remsen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rem Remson's will, bequeathing his estate to his brothers Isaac, John, Jacob and Joris, as well as his sisters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jacob Remsen's will, bequeathing his estate to his son Isaac and sons-in-law Johannes Debevoise and Samuel Harris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joris Remsen's will.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A document signed by Jacobus Lefferts, surrogate of Kings County, declaring Jacob Remsen's will authentic. It lists executors as Isaac Remsen, Johannes Debevoise, and Samuel Harris. Included is a copy of the 1785 will.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A document signed by Jacobus Lefferts, surrogate of Kings County, declaring Joris Remsen's will authentic. It names John Ditmars and Samuel Harris as executors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jeremiah Remsen to Isaac Remsen for land south of Flatbush.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Isaac Remsen purchased 66 acres from Jacob Buys.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Isaak [Isaac] Remsen purchased land from Matthys Corvoliuys [?], known as "Cripplebush" in the area known as "Brookland."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Isaac Remsen of "Crupplebush" bought 4 acres of land from Cornelius, Johannes, and David van Cats of Bushwyck.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Isaac Remsen obtained an "upland swamp" near "Criepelbos" from the Town of Brooklyn. It was bounded on the north by Jeremiah Remsen's land.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Isaac Remsen and Jacques Durje [Duryea?] bought 96 acres of land from Joseph Hegeman Tun and Arianje his wife, bound on the northwest by the highway leading from Bushwick to the ferry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Isaak Remse" purchased 6 acres of land in "Bruckland…a-long the road that leadeth to the ferry of New York" from Johannes Cushow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joris Remsen paid Rem Remsen for land in "Crupelbos," Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Remsen's farm and property in Brooklyn Woods, New Lots, and Bushwick were put up for sale. Johannes Ditmars and Samuel Harris were executors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: List of heirs of Joris Remsen's estate. Includes dozens of signatures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Apparently a draft of a will by Martin Schenk [Sr.?] dividing his estate into three parts, to be given to his sons Martin and Lambert and his daughter Anne Schenk Skillman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Grennelle of Dutchess County and William Nicholl of Islip, Long Island were bound to Martin Schenk [Sr.?] for 400 pounds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Survey for Martin and Lambert Schenk of their farms in Brooklyn by Peter Vandervoort.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Road access to Lambert Schenk from Martin and Sarah Schenk. Lambert's copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Same as above, except it is Martin and Sarah's copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Martin Schenk bonded to Mercy Conselyea of Bushwick for $400. The bond was paid off in 1811.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Martin Schenk borrowed $4,125 from Jacobus Suydam of Newtown, Queens County.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lambert Schenk bought land and a house from Jacobus Suydam of Newtown, Queens County. The property was situated on the road from Newtown to Brooklyn through the "Wallabought" [Wallabout Bay]. It bordered the land of Martin Schenk. The signature is missing from this document.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Martin Schenk purchased land bordering the highway from Bedford to New Lots from James Suydam of Newtown, Queens County.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Martin and Sarah Schenk probably cosigned this mortgage from James Suydam for Ida Harris, Jane Schenk, and Jacob Harris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Johannes Fine bought 74 acres of land from Dorothy Verseiur [?] and Jocham, her son, of "Newtonne" [Newtown]. The property bordered that of Samuel Coe on the south side.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Johannes Fine purchased land from Thomas Pettit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Johannes Fyn [Fine?], a blacksmith, bought land from Thomas Pettit of Newtown, Queens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Barrent Lefferts and his wife "Phebe" sold land to Lambert Suydam, Hendrik E. Suydam, Abraham Debevoise, Benjamin Linchman, Jeremiah Remsen, Martin Schenk, and Francis Skillman. Witnessed by Johannes E. Lott.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Andrew Mercein mortgaged property to Isaac Harris located at Pearl and High Streets, Brooklyn. Formerly the property of Joshua Sands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dr. Stephen C. Roe of New York City sold land in Onondonga County, NY to George Bushe of New York City.
